title: Married couple's auction hack nets them a $1million three-bedroom townhouse
text:
A married couple used an auction hack to buy a three-bedroom townhouse in Melbourne, saving themselves up to $800,000.

The couple attended the auction on Saturday for a property in Hawthorn East with a controversial plan to fend off other prospective buyers.

The property features a large wrap around courtyard with an open plan kitchen and dining area and two private car spaces, only a short distance from Melbourne CBD.

Instead of bidding together, the couple stood apart and separately commanded the auction, intimidating other bidders out of the race.

A married couple have used a plan to buy a three-bedroom townhouse in Melbourne (pictured)

The property features a large wrap around courtyard with an open plan kitchen and dining area and two private car spaces, only a short distance from Melbourne CBD

The wife dropped out of the bidding race first, leaving the husband outstanding with the largest offer.

Ham Kerr Property sold the house to the couple for $1.07million.

Selling agent Joe Falzon said he had no idea the husband and wife were a team.

'Once she stopped bidding, the husband stepped in against the others, which is not a bad tactic,' Mr Falzon told the Herald Sun.

'They had spoken to a few friends before the auction who said it was a good ploy.'

Their tactic netted them the property nearly $800,000 under the Hawthorn East median house price.
description: The couple attended the auction on Saturday for a property in Hawthorn East with a clever plan to fend off other prospective buyers.
authors: Jackson Barron For Daily Mail Australia
